title: Landsker Borderlands Trail Walking Route

nearby.description: Lawrenny Quay and the Daugleddau River

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Landsker Borderlands Trail, Coed Howell
images.caption: Landsker Borderlands Trail, Coed Howell. The long distance path is seen here as it heads south to its starting point at Whitland. It is a circular route of about 60 miles (100 kms). The Landsker Line is an imaginary line 'separating the Welsh speaking North of Pembrokeshire from its English speaking south'.

images.title: R Simpson / Landsker Borderlands
images.caption: Landsker Borderlands Farmland. Wooded area with bike and footpath trails. Farm on left of picture is Danycoed.

images.title: welshbabe / Landsker Borderland's Trail, River Wenallt, Login
images.caption: River Wenallt. Here the trail crosses a footbridge over the small river Wenallt - more a stream.

images.title: welshbabe / Quiete Lane Towards The River Wenallt, Login
images.caption: Quiet Lane Towards The River Wenallt

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Aber Farm, Coed Howell
images.caption: Aber Farm, Coed Howell. The farm is in a valley formed by a small watercourse named Afon Gronw.

images.title: Hywel Williams / Stepping stones over the Cresswell
images.caption: Stepping stones over the Cresswell. This location is definitely not crossable 24 hours a day as the river is tidal here and the stepping stones are only accessible during low tide. Based on what I could see, they're uncrossable for about 3 hours each high tide making them unusable for about 6 hours in each day. They do form part of the trail.

images.title: ALAN SOUTHWORTH / Ogham stones
images.caption: Ogham stones. One of a number of groups of Ogham stones sited in different parts of Ireland. This particular group is situated Just outside the village of Beaufort in Co.Kerry. The edges of each stone is etched with various markings and were used as an early form of writing or communication.

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Footpath to Blaencilgoed Quarries
images.caption: Footpath to Blaencilgoed Quarries.

description: A super circular walk through the Pembrokeshire and Carmarthenshire countryside visting the River Cleddau estuary, the Ogham stones, the Norman castles at Llawhaden and Carew Castle as well as the prehistoric remains at Llawhaden. Part of the trail is used on the Lawrenny Quay and the Daugleddau River Walk. It explores a picturesque peninsula of the Cleddau estuary. You'll also pass close to Carew Castle where there's a splendid circular walk around the delightful mill pond.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: For more walking ideas in the area see the Pembrokeshire Coast Walks page.

display_address: A40, Llawhaden, Pembrokeshire, Cymru / Wales, SA67 8EB, United Kingdom
